FuncDef:
The domain-name-delimiter command configures the domain name delimiter to separate the domain name and user name.
The undo domain-name-delimiter command restores the default setting.
By default, the domain name delimiter is @.

ParaDef.Info:
Specifies the delimiter. For example, if the delimiter is configured as @, the user named user1 in the domain named dom1 is identified as user1@dom1.
The value can be \, /, :, <, >, |, @, ', or %.

Examples: Warning: After this operation, users that have configured with domain names will fail to log in. Continue? [Y/N]: Y
ExtraInfo:
Usage Scenario
The domain-name-delimiter configures the domain name delimiter to separate the domain name and user name. By default, the domain name delimiter is @. To configure another delimiter, run the domain-name-delimiter command.
If the user name of a local user contains delimiters, the user name changes synchronously after the delimiter is changed. For example, if a local user named Huawei123@123 exists, after the delimiter is changed from @ to |, the user name synchronously changes to Huawei123|123.
